labels.text: Between Clouds and Water from Peng Wei’s ongoing series (since 2005) Letters from a Distance shows her use of copying and appropriation of both Chinese and Western artistic tropes. The usual elements of Chinese landscape paintings are all present: mountains, rocks, and trees; a river and a waterfall; a pavilion and human figures.To add her own imagined narrative to the landscape, she juxtaposes aseemingly traditiona lscene with a love letter (as inscription) from the English poet Lord Byron (1788–1824) to his married Italian lover Teresa, Contessa Guiccioli (1800–1873). Peng designed and painted the patterns of the protective flaps of the scroll (both front and back), instead of using ready-made fabric,turningthe workintoanobjectof desire—a letter.

My dearest Teresa,

I have read this book in your garden;—my love, you were absent, or else I could not have read it. It is a favourite book of yours, and the writer was a friend of mine. You will not understand these English words, and others will not understand them, which is the reason I have not scrawled them in Italian. But you will recognise the hand-writing of him who passionately loved you, and you will divine that, over a book which was yours, he could only think of love. In that word, beautiful in all languages, but most so in yours—Amor mio—is comprised my existence here and hereafter. I feel I exist here, and I feel that I shall exist hereafter,—to what purpose you will decide; my destiny rests with you, and you are a woman, eighteen years of age, and two out of a convent. I wish that you had stayed there, with all my heart,—or, at least, that I had never met you in your married state. But all this is too late. I love you, and you love me,—at least, you say so, and act as if you did so, which last is a great consolation in all events. But I more than love you, and cannot cease to love you. Think of me, sometimes, when the Alps and ocean divide us,—but they never will, unless you wish it.

Byron.
Bologna, August 25, 1819.

In 1819 Byron met Countess Teresa Guiccioli, who later divorced her husband to become Byron’s lover. Byron had divorced his wife two years prior and went on a voyage in Europe. Copied from Byron’s correspondence by Peng Wei on 28 July 2013, in unbearable heat.

[The Chinese text is adapted from a translation of the English original in Letters and Journals of Lord Byron: with Notices of His Life published by H. L. Brönner in 1830. ]

《雲水隔》是彭薇自2005年創作至今的「遙遠的信件」系列作品之一，從中可見其沿襲並刻意挪用中國和西方藝術的手法。此作中畫有山石、樹木、河流、瀑布、亭台和人物，齊集山水畫常見的元素。彭薇為這幅傳統山水畫題上一封由英國詩人拜倫（1788–1824年）致意大利桂喬麗伯爵夫人泰麗莎（1800–1873年）的情信，為作品平添想像的情節。彭薇還親自設計並繪製了卷軸的天地頭，而非使用現成的花綾，令作品成為一件念想之物，一封慾念之信。

我最親愛的泰麗莎我在你的
花園里(裏)讀完了這本書我的愛人
妳不在否則我不可能讀完這是
你最喜歡的一本作者是我們的
朋友你是看不懂這封英文信的
別人也不懂這正是我沒寫意大利
文的原因但你認得炽(熾)愛你的人的
筆記而且你會猜到他在讀一本属于
(屬於)
你的書時心中想的衹能是愛情

這個詞在所有語言中都很美尤其在你
的語言中它包涵了我現在和今後存
在的意義我感到我現在生存著同
時也將在今後生存下去為什麼目的
這將由妳決定我的命運維系(繫)於妳
而妳一個貳九年華的女人從修道
院出來才兩年我真希望妳仍在
修道院或者至少我能在你未
嫁之時我(與)妳相逢

然而這一切為時已晚我愛你你也愛
我至少妳是這樣說的而且從妳的
行為看來好像也是如此這至少是
一大安慰可是我對妳的愛那麼深
而且永無止盡

萬一阿尔(爾)卑斯山和大海把妳我分
隔開來愿(願)你時時能想念我
不過我們永遠不會分離的除非
妳有這種意愿(願)

拜倫
一八一九年八月廿五日于(於)波洛那
拜倫兩年前與妻子離婚後到歐
洲漫游一九年在意大利认(認)識桂喬
麗伯爵夫人其後桂喬麗與丈夫
離婚成為拜倫的情人

貳零壹叁年七月廿八日彭薇
抄录(錄)拜倫書信酷热(熱)難熬

[ 改寫自《名人書信》（黃繼忠譯、中國對外翻譯有限公司於2008年出版。）]

images.AltText: Ink and colour on a long vertical hanging scroll. The top and bottom mounts of the scroll are drawn upon with coloured ink patterns consisting of Chinese knots and flowers. Underneath the upper mount are vertically ordered Chinese characters made up of narrow strokes. The main part of the scroll is a portrait-oriented landscape painting of rivers and mountains. In the foreground, a man and a woman stand on a bridge, making eye contact with a fisherman under the pine tree at right. Outside a pavilion in the middle ground, a woman leans on the door with the palm of her hand on her face.
images.AltTextTC: 水墨設色長立軸，頭尾兩端的天地頭以彩墨繪畫了由中式繩結和花卉組成的圖案。天頭下有細筆直書的中文字。立軸的主要部分是直幅的河溪山水，近景的一對男女立於小橋上，與右邊松樹下的漁夫相望，中景的樓房外有一掩面的女子倚門而站。
